## V-Dem: Our Most Comprehensive Framework

\begin{columns}[T]
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\begin{itemize}
\item Five dimensions of democracy tracked across 235+ years
\item Electoral, Liberal, Participatory, Deliberative, Egalitarian
\item \textbf{This represents the most sophisticated and comprehensive measurement framework in comparative politics}
\item Used by scholars, policymakers, and international organizations as the authoritative standard for assessing democratic quality
\item Captures institutional arrangements, procedural protections, and formal political rights across states and time
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{~/Desktop/Slides/Fig2_Five_Dimensions.png}
\end{column}
\end{columns}

## The Puzzle

\begin{columns}[T]
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{0.48 = "moderately democratic"} for period 1789-1920
\item \textbf{Reality check for this "moderately democratic" era:}
  \begin{itemize}
  \item 100\% of women excluded
  \item Black Americans enslaved $\rightarrow$ disenfranchised $\rightarrow$ terrorized
  \item White male monopoly on citizenship and power
  \end{itemize}
\item \textbf{Problem: Procedures look democratic while power stays monopolized}
\item \textbf{Missing: Who actually holds power} vs. how institutions function
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{~/Desktop/Slides/Fig1_VDem_Puzzle.png}
\end{column}
\end{columns}

## The Measurement Gap

\begin{columns}[T]
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\textbf{What we measure:}
\begin{itemize}
\item How institutions constrain each other
\item Whether formal procedures exist
\item Rights protections on paper
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\textbf{What we don't measure:}
\begin{itemize}
\item Which groups actually hold power
\item Whether power is monopolized or shared
\item Group exclusion vs. group inclusion
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\end{columns}

\vspace{0.5cm}

\textbf{\textcolor{CoralAccent}{Bottom line: Both matter for democracy. Only one has been systematically measured.}}

## Democracy for the Master Race

\begin{columns}[T]
\begin{column}{0.35\textwidth}
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{~/Desktop/Slides/Race and Racism Book Cover.jpg}
\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.6\textwidth}
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Herrenvolk Democracy = democracy for the master race} (herren = master, volk = people)
\item Van den Berghe (1967): \textbf{"Democracy for the master race, tyranny for subordinate groups"}
\item \textbf{Core characteristics:}
  \begin{itemize}
  \item Functional democratic institutions among dominant group
  \item Systematic exclusion of subordinate groups
  \item Democratic and exclusionary components \textbf{mutually reinforcing}
  \end{itemize}
\item Found across cases: US Jim Crow, South African apartheid, colonial democracies
\item \textbf{The measurement blindspot:}
  \begin{itemize}
  \item When exclusions are treated as aberrations, not features, measures focus on institutions
  \item Result: \textbf{We measure institutional arrangements, miss group-level power monopolization}
  \end{itemize}
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\end{columns}

## The US Case: Herrenvolk Democracy by Design

\begin{columns}[T]
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{1790 Naturalization Act:} Citizenship restricted to \textbf{"free white persons"}
\item \textbf{First Congress, third law:} They codified herrenvolk democracy immediately---\textbf{not as evolution, but as foundation}
\item Remained law for \textbf{162 years} (until 1952)
\item \textbf{This created:}
  \begin{itemize}
  \item Legal monopoly on political power by one group
  \item Functional democratic institutions within that group
  \item Separation of powers, electoral competition, rights---\textbf{for some}
  \end{itemize}
\item \textbf{\textcolor{CoralAccent}{Herrenvolk democracy was the design, not a deviation}}
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{~/Desktop/Slides/1790 Naturalization Act.png}
\end{column}
\end{columns}

## Exclusion as System Maintenance

\begin{columns}[T]
\begin{column}{0.55\textwidth}
\begin{itemize}
\item These aren't just "bad things that happened"---\textbf{they're herrenvolk democracy maintenance}
\item \textbf{1790-1952:} Only "free white persons" can naturalize \textbf{(162 years)}
\item \textbf{1857:} Dred Scott - Black Americans cannot be citizens
\item \textbf{1890s-1965:} Jim Crow disenfranchisement and terror
\item \textbf{Through 1920:} All women excluded from political power
\item \textbf{1924:} Indigenous peoples granted citizenship
\item \textbf{Pattern continues:} Latino exclusion through conquest, deportation, contemporary restrictions
\item \textbf{\textcolor{CoralAccent}{Each group faces systematic, legal exclusion from political power}}
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.4\textwidth}
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{~/Desktop/Slides/US Map 1830s.png}
\end{column}
\end{columns}

## Tocqueville Saw the Real Test

\begin{columns}[T]
\begin{column}{0.55\textwidth}
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Tocqueville's observation:} \textit{"The prejudice of race appears stronger in states that abolished slavery"}
\item \textbf{His prediction:} \textit{"Slavery recedes, but the prejudice to which it has given birth is immovable"}
\item \textbf{The real question he was asking:} What happens to democracy when subordinate groups demand equality? \textbf{Will the dominant group share power?}
\item Tocqueville identified \textbf{group-level power tensions as THE central challenge} to American democracy
\item Yet \textbf{the herrenvolk democracy blindspot has persisted}---we haven't reckoned with his insight
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.4\textwidth}
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{~/Desktop/Slides/Tocqueville.jpg}
\end{column}
\end{columns}

## Power-Sharing: The Missing Dimension

\begin{block}{Power-Sharing Democracy}
Political power distributed across social groups, not monopolized
\end{block}

\vspace{0.3cm}

\textbf{Why a distinct dimension:}

\begin{itemize}
\item Democratic theory recognizes group power-sharing as fundamental to democracy
\item But it's \textbf{never been operationalized as a dimension} like electoral or liberal democracy
\item You can have \textbf{high electoral + low power-sharing} (Jim Crow)
\item You can have \textbf{high egalitarian + low power-sharing} (equality within restricted demos)
\end{itemize}

\vspace{0.3cm}

\begin{columns}[T]
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\textbf{V-Dem's five dimensions ask:} Do institutions check each other?
\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\textbf{Power-Sharing asks:} Do groups share power?
\end{column}
\end{columns}

\vspace{0.2cm}

\textbf{\textcolor{CoralAccent}{Both questions matter. We've measured one systematically, not the other.}}

## Building the Power-Sharing Index

\begin{columns}[T]
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Built from 7 V-Dem indicators measuring group-level power dynamics:}
  \begin{itemize}
  \item Suffrage (\% with legal right to vote)
  \item Social group equality in civil liberties
  \item Gender power distribution
  \item Women's and men's access to justice
  \item Power distribution by social group
  \item Class equality in civil liberties
  \end{itemize}
\item \textbf{Proof of concept:}
  \begin{itemize}
  \item Leverages V-Dem's existing data
  \item Combined them to create a Power-Sharing measure
  \item Demonstrates \textbf{we can measure group power-sharing systematically}
  \end{itemize}
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{~/Desktop/Slides/Power-Sharing Index.png}
\end{column}
\end{columns}

## Contemporary Herrenvolk Dynamics

\begin{columns}[T]
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\textbf{The standard story:}
\begin{itemize}
\item Institutions are breaking down
\item Norms are eroding
\item Democracy is backsliding
\end{itemize}

\vspace{0.3cm}

\textbf{But look at what's actually happening:}
\begin{itemize}
\item Voter suppression targeting Black, Latino, and young voters
\item Gerrymandering along racial lines
\item Citizenship restrictions determining who belongs
\item Attacks on diversity and inclusion
\end{itemize}

\vspace{0.3cm}

\textbf{This isn't institutional decay. This is power-sharing contestation.}

\textbf{The red flag:} If our measures missed herrenvolk democracy for 162 years, are they missing it now?
\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{~/Desktop/Slides/Decline of Democracy 2025.png}
\end{column}
\end{columns}

## Tocqueville's Question, America's Crossroads

\textbf{The Tocqueville tension remains unresolved}

\textbf{Herrenvolk democracy is still alive and well}---creating an unavoidable choice:

\vspace{0.3cm}

\begin{columns}[T]
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\textbf{Option 1: Multiracial Power-Sharing Democracy}
\begin{itemize}
\item Political power genuinely distributed across groups
\item Multiracial coalition governance
\item Would be \textbf{first time in 235 years}
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\textbf{Option 2: Maintain Group Power Monopoly}
\begin{itemize}
\item Requires abandoning democratic forms
\item Minority rule through institutional mechanisms
\item Authoritarianism when power-sharing becomes impossible
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\end{columns}

\vspace{0.5cm}

\textbf{\textcolor{CoralAccent}{The Power-Sharing Index helps us understand these dynamics and tensions}}

## Building a Better Power-Sharing Index

\textbf{Current approach: Proof of concept using existing V-Dem data}

\vspace{0.3cm}

\textbf{What would ideal measures capture?}

\begin{columns}[T]
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Direct representation by group} (actual vs. proportional seats in legislatures)
\item \textbf{Economic power distribution} across groups (wealth, business ownership, capital control)
\item \textbf{State violence patterns by group} (policing, incarceration, use of force)
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.48\textwidth}
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Policy responsiveness by group} (when groups mobilize, do policies change?)
\item \textbf{Access to appointive offices} (cabinet, courts, bureaucracy)
\item \textbf{Citizenship and naturalization patterns} (who gets in, how easily?)
\end{itemize}
\end{column}
\end{columns}

\vspace{0.5cm}

\textbf{\textcolor{CoralAccent}{Question for discussion: What would strengthen this measurement approach?}}
